Class Rational

  • java.lang.Object
    • Rational
  • public class Rational
extends java.lang.Object
    The Rational program implements an application that can perform arithmetic operations with rational numbers. The program is implemented through a class named Rational and the main class where the objects are created and called.
    Author:
    Osman

      • inputRational

        public Rational inputRational()
        Public method that takes the input from the user to set the values of the numerator and denominator. Uses Scanner class to take user input. myVal is a Scanner object.
        Returns:
        This method requires a Rational value to be returned so I called the two argument Constructor after setting the new values

        Public method that takes the numerator and denominator values and puts it into the correct format.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        The num/den format as a String.

      • add

        public void add​(Rational r1,
                Rational r2)
        This public method adds two rational objects through the calling object. The keyword this represents the current object; in this case r3 is calling the add method with r1 and r2 as it's parameters. The rational fractions need the same denominators to add so they are multiplied by each other's denominators. The method gcd is also called in order to find the greatest common divisor of the final added value to reduce the fraction.
        Parameters:
        r1 - Represents the rational object r1 created in main
        r2 - Represents the rational object r2 created in main

      • sub

        public Rational sub​(Rational r)
        This public method subtracts two rational objects through the calling object. In this case I created two values representing the new numerator and denominator. As with addition the denominators must be the same for subtraction. The calling object is r1 in this case and is multiplied by r2's denominator and the same is done for r2's numerator by r1's denominator.
        Parameters:
        r - The parameter represents the rational object r2 being called by r1
        Returns:
        This method requires a Rational value to be returned so I called the two argument Constructor to set the new values and returned it in the variable sub

      • mul

        public void mul​(Rational r1,
                Rational r2)
        This public method multiplies two rational objects through the calling object. The keyword this represents the current object; in this case r3 is calling the mul method with r1 and r2 as it's parameters. This one also calls gcd in order to reduce the final result.
        Parameters:
        r1 - r1 Represents the rational object r1 created in main
        r2 - r2 Represents the rational object r2 created in main

      • div

        public Rational div​(Rational R)
        This public method divides two rational objects through the calling object. As with the subtract method I created two new variables which will store the divided values of the final result. The calling object is r1 and multiples with denominator of r2 because division is the same as multiplication of the reciprocal. The method gcd is called in order to reduce the result.
        Parameters:
        R - The parameter represents the rational object r2 being called by r1
        Returns:
        This method requires a Rational value to be returned so I called the two argument Constructor to set the new values and returned it in variable div

      • divToDouble

        public static double divToDouble​(Rational r1,
                                 Rational r2)
        This public static method can be accessed by calling the Rational class and using the dot operator with the two objects r1, and r2 as the parameters. The method displays the real value of rational r1 divided by rational r2.
        Parameters:
        r1 - r1 Represents the rational object r1 created in main
        r2 - r2 Represents the rational object r2 created in main
        Returns:
        Returns the result of the division as a real number in the variable result
